pages.title: Alternated octagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U433_0}} In [[geometry]], the '''tritetragonal tiling''' or '''alternated octagonal tiling''' is a [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform]] [[tessellation|tiling]] of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]]s of {(4,3,3)} or h{8,3}. == Geometry == Although a sequence of edges seem to represent straight lines (projected into curves), careful attention will show they are not straight, as can be seen by looking at it from different projective centers. {| class=wikitable width=480 |- align=center |[[File:Uniform tiling 433-t0 3-fold.png|160px]]
Triangle-centered
hyperbolic straight edges |[[File:Uniform tiling 433-t0 edgecenter.png|160px]]
Edge-centered
projective straight edges |[[File:Uniform tiling 433-t0 point.png|160px]]
Point-centered
projective straight edges |} == Dual tiling== [[File:Uniform dual tiling 433-t0.png|240px]] == In art == [[Circle Limit III]] is a [[woodcut]] made in 1959 by Dutch artist [[M. C. Escher]], in which "strings of fish shoot up like rockets from infinitely far away" and then "fall back again whence they came". White curves within the figure, through the middle of each line of fish, divide the plane into squares and triangles in the pattern of the tritetragonal tiling. However, in the tritetragonal tiling, the corresponding curves are chains of hyperbolic line segments, with a slight angle at each vertex, while in Escher's woodcut they appear to be smooth [[Hypercycle (geometry)|hypercycle]]s. :[[File:Circle limits III with overlay.png|240px]] == Related polyhedra and tiling == {{Order 4-3-3 tiling table}} {{Order 4-4-4 tiling table}} ==See also== *''[[Circle Limit III]]'' *[[Square tiling]] *[[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane]] *[[List of regular polytopes]] ==References== * [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{ISBN|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations) * {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}} == External links == {{Commonscat|Uniform tiling 3-4-3-4-3-4}} * Douglas Dunham Department of Computer Science University of Minnesota, Duluth ** [http://www.d.umn.edu/~ddunham/isis4/section6.html Examples Based on Circle Limits III and IV], 2006:[http://www.d.umn.edu/~ddunham/dunbrid06.pdf More “Circle Limit III” Patterns], 2007:[http://www.d.umn.edu/~ddunham/dunbrid07.pdf A “Circle Limit III” Calculation], 2008:[http://www.d.umn.edu/~ddunham/bridges08.pdf A “Circle Limit III” Backbone Arc Formula] *{{MathWorld | urlname= HyperbolicTiling | title = Hyperbolic tiling}} *{{MathWorld | urlname=PoincareHyperbolicDisk | title = Poincaré hyperbolic disk }} * [http://bork.hampshire.edu/~bernie/hyper/ Hyperbolic and Spherical Tiling Gallery] * [http://geometrygames.org/KaleidoTile/index.html KaleidoTile 3: Educational software to create spherical, planar and hyperbolic tilings] * [http://www.plunk.org/~hatch/HyperbolicTesselations Hyperbolic Planar Tessellations, Don Hatch] {{Tessellation}} [[Category:Hyperbolic tilings]] [[Category:Isogonal tilings]] [[Category:Uniform tilings]] [[Category:Octagonal tilings]] {{geometry-stub}}

pages.title: Alternated order-4 hexagonal tiling
Cantic octagonal tiling
Cantic order-4 hexagonal tiling
Circle Limit III
pages.text:
{{Italic title}}
[[File:Escher Circle Limit III.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|''Circle Limit III'', 1959]]
'''''Circle Limit III''''' is a [[woodcut]] made in 1959 by Dutch artist [[M. C. Escher]], in which "strings of fish shoot up like rockets from infinitely far away" and then "fall back again whence they came".<ref name="eq">Escher, as quoted by {{harvtxt|Coxeter|1979}}.</ref>

It is one of a series of four woodcuts by Escher depicting ideas from [[hyperbolic geometry]]. Dutch physicist and mathematician Bruno Ernst called it "the best of the four".<ref name="cox79">{{citation|first=H. S. M.|last=Coxeter|authorlink=Harold Scott MacDonald Coxeter|title=The non-Euclidean symmetry of Escher's picture 'Circle Limit III'|journal=Leonardo|volume=12|pages=19–25|year=1979|jstor=1574078}}.</ref>

==Inspiration==
[[File:Hyperbolic domains 642.png|left|thumb|upright=0.8|The (6,4,2) triangular hyperbolic tiling that inspired Escher]]
Escher became interested in [[tessellation|tessellations of the plane]] after a 1936 visit to the [[Alhambra]] in [[Granada]], Spain,<ref name="emmer">{{citation
 | last = Emmer | first = Michele
 | doi = 10.1142/S0219887806001594
 | issue = 5-6
 | journal = International Journal of Geometric Methods in Modern Physics
 | mr = 2264394
 | pages = 869–879
 | title = Escher, Coxeter and symmetry
 | volume = 3
 | year = 2006}}.</ref><ref name="mside">{{citation|first=Doris|last=Schattschneider|authorlink=Doris Schattschneider|title=The mathematical side of M. C. Escher|url=http://www.ams.org/notices/201006/rtx100600706p.pdf|journal=Notices of the AMS|volume=57|issue=6|pages=706–718|year=2010}}.</ref>
and from the time of his 1937 artwork ''[[Metamorphosis I]]'' he had begun incorporating tessellated human and animal figures into his artworks.<ref name="mside"/>

In a 1958 letter from Escher to [[Harold Scott MacDonald Coxeter|H. S. M. Coxeter]], Escher wrote that he was inspired to make his ''Circle Limit'' series by a figure in Coxeter's article "Crystal 
Symmetry and its Generalizations".<ref name="cox79"/><ref name="emmer"/> Coxeter's figure depicts a [[tessellation]] of the [[hyperbolic plane]] by [[right triangle]]s with angles of 30°, 45°, and 90°; triangles with these angles are possible in hyperbolic geometry but not in Euclidean geometry. This tessellation may be interpreted as depicting the lines of reflection and fundamental domains of the [[Truncated tetrahexagonal tiling|(6,4,2)]] [[triangle group]].<ref>Coxeter expanded on the mathematics of triangle group tessellations, including this one in {{citation
 | last = Coxeter | first = H. S. M. | authorlink = Harold Scott MacDonald Coxeter
 | doi = 10.4153/CMB-1997-019-0
 | issue = 2
 | journal = Canadian Mathematical Bulletin
 | mr = 1451269
 | pages = 158–168
 | title = The trigonometry of hyperbolic tessellations
 | volume = 40
 | year = 1997}}.</ref> An elementary analysis of Coxeter's figure, as Escher might have understood it, is given by {{harvtxt|Casselman|2010}}.<ref>{{citation|title=How did Escher do it?|first=Bill|last=Casselman|url=http://www.ams.org/samplings/feature-column/fcarc-circle-limit|series=AMS Feature Column|date=June 2010}}.</ref>
{{-}}

==Geometry==
[[File:Circle limits III with overlay.png|thumb|The [[alternated octagonal tiling]], a [[uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|hyperbolic tiling]] of squares and equilateral triangles, overlaid on Escher's image]]
Escher seems to have believed that the white curves of his woodcut, which bisect the fish, represent hyperbolic lines in the [[Poincaré disk model]] of the hyperbolic plane, in which the whole hyperbolic plane is modeled as a disk in the Euclidean plane, and hyperbolic lines are modeled as circular arcs perpendicular to the disk boundary. Indeed, Escher wrote that the fish move "perpendicularly to the boundary".<ref name="eq"/> However, as Coxeter demonstrated, there is no hyperbolic [[arrangement of lines]] whose faces are alternately squares and equilateral triangles, as the figure depicts. Rather, the white curves are [[Hypercycle (geometry)|hypercycles]] that meet the boundary circle at angles of {{nowrap|cos<sup>−1</sup> {{sfrac|2<sup>{{1/4}}</sup> − 2<sup>−{{1/4}}</sup>|2}},}} approximately 80°.<ref name="cox79"/>

The symmetry axes of the triangles and squares that lie between the white lines are true hyperbolic lines. The squares and triangles of the woodcut closely resemble the [[alternated octagonal tiling]] of the hyperbolic plane, which also features squares and triangles meeting in the same incidence pattern.
However, the precise geometry of these shapes is not the same. In the alternated octagonal tiling tiling, the sides of the squares and triangles are hyperbolically straight line segments, which do not link up in smooth curves; instead they form [[polygonal chain]]s with corners. In Escher's woodcut, the sides of the squares and triangles are formed by arcs of hypercycles, which are not straight in hyperbolic geometry, but which connect smoothly to each other without corners.

The points at the centers of the squares, where four fish meet at their fins, form the vertices of an [[order-8 triangular tiling]], while the points where three fish fins meet and the points where three white lines cross together form the vertices of its [[Dual polyhedron|dual]], the [[octagonal tiling]].<ref name="cox79"/> Similar tessellations by lines of fish may be constructed for other hyperbolic tilings formed by [[polygon]]s other than triangles and squares, or with more than three white curves at each crossing.<ref>{{citation|first=Douglas|last=Dunham|contribution=More “Circle Limit III” patterns|url=https://www.d.umn.edu/~ddunham/dunbrid06.pdf|title=The Bridges Conference: Mathematical Connections in Art, Music, and Science, London, 2006}}.</ref>

Euclidean coordinates of circles containing the three most prominent white curves in the woodcut may be obtained by calculations in the field of rational numbers extended by the square roots of two and three.<ref>{{citation|first=H. S. M.|last=Coxeter|authorlink=Harold Scott MacDonald Coxeter|contribution=The trigonometry of Escher’s woodcut ''Circle Limit III''|title=M.C.Escher’s Legacy: A Centennial Celebration|year=2003|publisher=Springer|pages=297–304|doi=10.1007/3-540-28849-X_29}}.</ref>

==Symmetry==
Viewed as a pattern, ignoring the colors of the fish, in the hyperbolic plane, the woodcut has three-fold and four-fold [[rotational symmetry]] at the centers of its triangles and squares, respectively, and order-three [[dihedral symmetry]] (the symmetry of an equilateral triangle) at the points where the white curves cross. In [[John Horton Conway|John Conway]]'s [[orbifold notation]], this set of symmetries is denoted 433. Each fish provides a fundamental region for this symmetry group. Contrary to appearances, the fish do not have [[bilateral symmetry]]: the white curves of the drawing are not axes of reflection symmetry.<ref>{{citation
 | last = Conway | first = J. H. | authorlink = John Horton Conway
 | contribution = The orbifold notation for surface groups
 | doi = 10.1017/CBO9780511629259.038
 | location = Cambridge
 | mr = 1200280
 | pages = 438–447
 | publisher = Cambridge Univ. Press
 | series = London Math. Soc. Lecture Note Ser.
 | title = Groups, Combinatorics & Geometry (Durham, 1990)
 | volume = 165
 | year = 1992}}. Conway wrote that "The work ''Circle Limit III'' is equally intriguing" (in comparison to ''Circle Limit IV'', which has a different symmetry group), and uses is it as an example of this symmetry group.</ref><ref>{{citation|first=Peter|last=Herford|title=The geometry of M. C. Escher's circle-Limit-Woodcuts|journal=Zentralblatt für Didaktik der Mathematik|year=1999|volume=31|issue=5|pages=144–148|doi=10.1007/BF02659805}}. Paper presented to the 8th International Conference on Geometry, Nahsholim (Israel), March 7–14, 1999.</ref>
For example, the angle at the back of the right fin is 90° (where four fins meet), but at the back of the much smaller left fin it is 120° (where three fins meet).

==Printing details==
The fish in ''Circle Limit III'' are depicted in four colors, allowing each string of fish to have a single color and each two adjacent fish to have different colors. Together with the black ink used to outline the fish, the overall woodcut has five colors. It is printed from five wood blocks, each of which provides one of the colors within a quarter of the disk, for a total of 20 impressions. The diameter of the outer circle, as printed, is {{cvt|41.5|cm|frac=8}}.<ref>{{citation|title=M. C. Escher: The Graphic Work|page=10|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lq-EZiRdPswC&pg=PR1|publisher=Taschen|year=2001|first=M. C.|last=Escher}}.</ref>

==Exhibits==
As well as being included in the collection of the [[Escher Museum]] in [[The Hague]], there is a copy of ''Circle Limit III'' in the collection of the [[National Gallery of Canada]].<ref>[http://www.gallery.ca/en/see/collections/artwork.php?mkey=80 ''Circle Limit III''], [[National Gallery of Canada]], retrieved 2013-07-09.</ref>

pages.title: Heptagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Reg hyperbolic tiling stat table|U73_0}} In [[geometry]], the '''heptagonal tiling''' is a [[regular hyperbolic tiling|regular tiling]] of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It is represented by [[Schläfli symbol]] of {7,3}, having three regular [[heptagon]]s around each vertex. == Images == {| class=wikitable width=480 |- align=center |[[File:PavageDemiPlanPoincare.svg|160px]]
[[Poincaré half-plane model]] |[[File:PavageHypPoincare2.svg|160px]]
[[Poincaré disk model]] |[[File:PavageKleinBeltrami.svg|160px]]
[[Beltrami-Klein model]] |} == Related polyhedra and tilings == This tiling is topologically related as a part of sequence of regular polyhedra with [[Schläfli symbol]] {n,3}. {{Order-3 tiling table}} From a [[Wythoff construction]] there are eight hyperbolic [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform tilings]] that can be based from the regular heptagonal tiling. Drawing the tiles colored as red on the original faces, yellow at the original vertices, and blue along the original edges, there are 8 forms. {{Heptagonal tiling table}} == Hurwitz surfaces == [[File:3-7 kisrhombille.svg|thumb|The symmetry group of the heptagonal tiling has fundamental domain the (2,3,7) [[Schwarz triangle]], which yields this tiling.]] {{see|Hurwitz surface}} The symmetry group of the tiling is the [[(2,3,7) triangle group]], and a [[fundamental domain]] for this action is the (2,3,7) [[Schwarz triangle]]. This is the smallest hyperbolic Schwarz triangle, and thus, by the proof of [[Hurwitz's automorphisms theorem]], the tiling is the universal tiling that covers all [[Hurwitz surface]]s (the [[Riemann surface]]s with maximal symmetry group), giving them a tiling by heptagons whose symmetry group equals their automorphism group as Riemann surfaces. The smallest Hurwitz surface is the [[Klein quartic]] (genus 3, automorphism group of order 168), and the induced tiling has 24 heptagons, meeting at 56 vertices. The dual [[order-7 triangular tiling]] has the same symmetry group, and thus yields [[Polygon triangulation|triangulation]]s of Hurwitz surfaces. ==See also== {{Commonscat|Order-3 heptagonal tiling}} *[[Hexagonal tiling]] *[[Tilings of regular polygons]] *[[List of uniform planar tilings]] *[[List of regular polytopes]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{refbegin}} * [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{ISBN|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations) * {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}} {{refend}} == External links == *{{MathWorld | urlname= HyperbolicTiling | title = Hyperbolic tiling}} *{{MathWorld | urlname=PoincareHyperbolicDisk | title = Poincaré hyperbolic disk }} * [http://bork.hampshire.edu/~bernie/hyper/ Hyperbolic and Spherical Tiling Gallery] * [http://geometrygames.org/KaleidoTile/index.html KaleidoTile 3: Educational software to create spherical, planar and hyperbolic tilings] * [http://www.plunk.org/~hatch/HyperbolicTesselations Hyperbolic Planar Tessellations, Don Hatch] {{Tessellation}} [[Category:Heptagonal tilings| ]] [[Category:Hyperbolic tilings]] [[Category:Isogonal tilings]] [[Category:Isohedral tilings]] [[Category:Regular tilings]]

pages.title: Heptagrammic-order heptagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Reg hyperbolic tiling stat table|U7H_0}}
In [[geometry]], the '''heptagrammic-order heptagonal tiling''' is a [[List_of_regular_polytopes#Hyperbolic_tilings|regular]] star-tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of {7,7/2}. The vertex figure [[heptagram]]s are {7/2}, [[File:Obtuse heptagram.svg|40px]]. The heptagonal faces overlap with [[Density (polytope)|density]] 3.

== Related tilings==
It has the same [[vertex arrangement]] as the regular [[order-7 triangular tiling]], {3,7}. The full set of edges coincide with the edges of a [[heptakis heptagonal tiling]].
:[[File:Order-7 triangular tiling.svg|160px]][[File:Order3 heptakis heptagonal til.png|160px]]

It is related to a [[Kepler-Poinsot polyhedron]], the [[great dodecahedron]], {5,5/2}, which is polyhedron and a [[Density_(polytope)|density]]-3 regular star-tiling on the sphere (resembling a regular icosahedron in this state, similarly to this tessellation resembling the order-7 triangular tiling):
:[[File:Great dodecahedron tiling.png|240px]]

==References==
* [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{ISBN|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations)
* {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}}

==See also==

{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Reg hyperbolic tiling stat table|Ui3_2}} [[File:H3 33inf UHS plane at infinity.png|thumb|The [[Infinite-order tetrahedral honeycomb|{3,3,∞}]] honeycomb has {3,∞} vertex figures.]] In [[geometry]], the '''infinite-order triangular tiling''' is a [[regular hyperbolic tiling|regular tiling]] of the [[hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]] with a [[Schläfli symbol]] of {3,∞}. All vertices are ''ideal'', located at "infinity" and seen on the boundary of the [[Poincaré hyperbolic disk]] projection. == Symmetry == A lower symmetry form has alternating colors, and represented by cyclic symbol {(3,∞,3)}, {{CDD|node_1|split1|branch|labelinfin}}. The tiling also represents the fundamental domains of the [[Iii symmetry|*∞∞∞ symmetry]], which can be seen with 3 colors of lines representing 3 mirrors of the construction. {| class=wikitable width=450 |- align=center |[[File:Infinite-order triangular tiling.svg|150px]]
Alternated colored tiling |[[File:Iii symmetry mirrors.png|150px]]
*∞∞∞ symmetry |[[File:Apolleangasket symmetry.png|150px]]
[[Apollonian gasket]] with *∞∞∞ symmetry |} ==Related polyhedra and tiling== This tiling is topologically related as part of a sequence of regular polyhedra with [[Schläfli symbol]] {3,p}. {{Triangular regular tiling}} {{Order i-3 tiling table}} {{Order_i-3-3_tiling_table}} ===Other infinite-order triangular tilings=== A nonregular infinite-order triangular tiling can be generated by a [[Recursion (computer science)|recursive]] process from a central triangle as shown here: :[[File:Ideal-triangle hyperbolic tiling.svg|240px]] ==See also== {{Commons category|Infinite-order triangular tiling}} *[[Infinite-order tetrahedral honeycomb]] *[[List of regular polytopes]] *[[List of uniform planar tilings]] *[[Tilings of regular polygons]] *[[Triangular tiling]] *[[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane]] ==References== * [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{ISBN|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations) * {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}} ==External links== *{{MathWorld | urlname= HyperbolicTiling | title = Hyperbolic tiling}} *{{MathWorld | urlname=PoincareHyperbolicDisk | title = Poincaré hyperbolic disk}} {{Tessellation}} [[Category:Hyperbolic tilings]] [[Category:Infinite-order tilings]] [[Category:Isogonal tilings]] [[Category:Isohedral tilings]] [[Category:Regular tilings]] [[Category:Triangular tilings]]

pages.title: Octagonal tiling
Order-3 apeirogonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Reg hyperbolic tiling stat table|Ui3_0}} In [[geometry]], the '''order-3 apeirogonal tiling''' is a [[regular hyperbolic tiling|regular tiling]] of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It is represented by the [[Schläfli symbol]] {∞,3}, having three regular [[Apeirogon#Hyperbolic geometry|apeirogon]]s around each vertex. Each apeirogon is [[Circumscribed circle|inscribed]] in a [[horocycle]]. The [[order-2 apeirogonal tiling]] represents an infinite [[dihedron]] in the Euclidean plane as {∞,2}. ==Images== Each [[apeirogon]] face is [[circumscribe]]d by a [[horocycle]], which looks like a circle in a [[Poincaré disk model]], internally tangent to the projective circle boundary. :[[File:Order-3 apeirogonal tiling one cell horocycle.png|240px]] == Uniform colorings == Like the Euclidean [[Hexagonal tiling#Uniform colorings|hexagonal tiling]], there are 3 uniform colorings of the ''order-3 apeirogonal tiling'', each from different reflective [[triangle group]] domains: {|class=wikitable ![[List of regular polytopes#Hyperbolic tilings|Regular]] !colspan=3|[[Truncation (geometry)|Truncations]] |- align=center |[[File:H2 tiling 23i-1.png|120px]]
{∞,3}
{{CDD|node_1|infin|node|3|node}} |[[File:H2 tiling 2ii-3.png|120px]]
t0,1{∞,∞}
{{CDD|node_1|infin|node_1|infin|node}} |[[File:H2 tiling 2ii-6.png|120px]]
t1,2{∞,∞}
{{CDD|node|infin|node_1|infin|node_1}} |[[File:H2 tiling iii-7.png|120px]]
t{∞[3]}
{{CDD|node_1|split1-ii|branch_11|labelinfin}} |- !Colspan=4|Hyperbolic [[triangle group]]s |- align=center |[[File:H2checkers 23i.png|120px]]
[∞,3] |colspan=2|[[File:H2checkers 2ii.png|120px]]
[∞,∞] |[[File:Infinite-order triangular tiling.svg|120px]]
[(∞,∞,∞)] |} === Symmetry=== The dual to this tiling represents the fundamental domains of [(∞,∞,∞)] (*∞∞∞) symmetry. There are 15 small index subgroups (7 unique) constructed from [(∞,∞,∞)] by mirror removal and alternation. Mirrors can be removed if its branch orders are all even, and cuts neighboring branch orders in half. Removing two mirrors leaves a half-order gyration point where the removed mirrors met. In these images fundamental domains are alternately colored black and white, and mirrors exist on the boundaries between colors. The symmetry can be doubled as [[ii2 symmetry|∞∞2 symmetry]] by adding a mirror bisecting the fundamental domain. Dividing a fundamental domain by 3 mirrors creates a [[i32 symmetry|∞32 symmetry]]. A larger subgroup is constructed [(∞,∞,∞*)], index 8, as (∞*∞∞) with gyration points removed, becomes (*∞∞). {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" !colspan=7| Subgroups of [(∞,∞,∞)] (*∞∞∞) |- |- align=center ![[Subgroup index|Index]] !1 !colspan=3|2 !colspan=2|4 |- align=center !Diagram |[[File:iii_symmetry_000.png|120px]] |[[File:iii_symmetry_a00.png|120px]] |[[File:iii_symmetry_0a0.png|120px]] |[[File:iii_symmetry_00a.png|120px]] |[[File:iii_symmetry_ab0.png|120px]] |[[File:iii_symmetry_xxx.png|120px]] |- align=center ![[Coxeter notation|Coxeter]] |[(∞,∞,∞)]
{{CDD|node_c1|split1-ii|branch_c3-2|labelinfin}} |[(1+,∞,∞,∞)]
{{CDD|labelh|node|split1-ii|branch_c3-2|labelinfin}} = {{CDD|labelinfin|branch_c3-2|iaib-cross|branch_c3-2|labelinfin}} |[(∞,1+,∞,∞)]
{{CDD|node_c1|split1-ii|branch_h0c2|labelinfin}} = {{CDD|labelinfin|branch_c1-2|iaib-cross|branch_c1-2|labelinfin}} |[(∞,∞,1+,∞)]

pages.title: Order-4 apeirogonal tiling
Order-4 heptagonal tiling
Order-4 hexagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Reg hyperbolic tiling stat table|U64_0}} In [[geometry]], the '''order-4 hexagonal tiling''' is a [[List of regular polytopes#Hyperbolic tilings|regular]] tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of {6,4}. == Symmetry == This tiling represents a hyperbolic [[kaleidoscope]] of 6 mirrors defining a regular hexagon fundamental domain. This symmetry by [[orbifold notation]] is called *222222 with 6 order-2 mirror intersections. In [[Coxeter notation]] can be represented as [6*,4], removing two of three mirrors (passing through the hexagon center). Adding a bisecting mirror through 2 vertices of a hexagonal fundamental domain defines a trapezohedral [[4422 symmetry|*4422 symmetry]]. Adding 3 bisecting mirrors through the vertices defines [[443 symmetry|*443 symmetry]]. Adding 3 bisecting mirrors through the edge defines [[3222 symmetry|*3222 symmetry]]. Adding all 6 bisectors leads to full [[642 symmetry|*642 symmetry]]. {| class=wikitable |- align=center |[[File:642 symmetry zz0.png|80px]]
*222222 |[[File:642 symmetry a00.png|80px]]
*443 |[[File:642 symmetry 0a0.png|80px]]
*3222 |[[File:642 symmetry 000.png|80px]]
*642 |} == Uniform colorings == There are 7 distinct [[uniform coloring]]s for the order-4 hexagonal tiling. They are similar to 7 of the [[Square tiling#Uniform colorings|uniform colorings of the square tiling]], but exclude 2 cases with order-2 gyrational symmetry. Four of them have reflective constructions and [[Coxeter diagram]]s while three of them are undercolorings. {| class=wikitable |+ Uniform constructions of 6.6.6.6 |- align=center ! !1 color !2 colors !colspan=2|3 and 2 colors !colspan=3|4, 3 and 2 colors |- align=center !Uniform

diagram]] |{{CDD|node_1|6|node|4|node}} |{{CDD|node_1|split1-66|nodes}} = {{CDD|node_1|6|node|4|node_h0}} |colspan=2|{{CDD|node|split1-66|branch_11}} = {{CDD|node|6|node_1|6|node_h0}} |colspan=3|{{CDD|branch_11|3a3b-cross|branch_11}} = {{CDD|node_h0|6|node_1|6|node_h0}} = {{CDD|node_1|6|node_g|4sg|node_g}} |} == Related polyhedra and tiling == This tiling is topologically related as a part of sequence of regular tilings with [[hexagon]]al faces, starting with the [[hexagonal tiling]], with [[Schläfli symbol]] {6,n}, and [[Coxeter diagram]] {{CDD|node_1|6|node|n|node}}, progressing to infinity. {{Hexagonal_regular_tilings}} This tiling is also topologically related as a part of sequence of regular polyhedra and tilings with four faces per vertex, starting with the [[octahedron]], with [[Schläfli symbol]] {n,4}, and Coxeter diagram {{CDD|node_1|n|node|4|node}}, with n progressing to infinity. {{Order-4_regular_tilings}} {{Quasiregular6 table}} {{Order 6-4 tiling table}} {{Order 6-6 tiling table}} {{Order 3-2-3-2 tiling table}} {{Order_3-2-2-2_tiling_table}} ==See also== {{Commons category|Order-4 hexagonal tiling}} *[[Square tiling]] *[[Tilings of regular polygons]] *[[List of uniform planar tilings]] *[[List of regular polytopes]] ==References== * [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{isbn|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations) * {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}} == External links == *{{MathWorld | urlname= HyperbolicTiling | title = Hyperbolic tiling}} *{{MathWorld | urlname=PoincareHyperbolicDisk | title = Poincaré hyperbolic disk }} * [http://bork.hampshire.edu/~bernie/hyper/ Hyperbolic and Spherical Tiling Gallery] * [http://geometrygames.org/KaleidoTile/index.html KaleidoTile 3: Educational software to create spherical, planar and hyperbolic tilings] * [http://www.plunk.org/~hatch/HyperbolicTesselations Hyperbolic Planar Tessellations, Don Hatch] {{Tessellation}} [[Category:Hexagonal tilings]] [[Category:Hyperbolic tilings]] [[Category:Isogonal tilings]] [[Category:Isohedral tilings]] [[Category:Order-4 tilings]] [[Category:Regular tilings]]

pages.title: Order-4 octagonal tiling
Order-4 pentagonal tiling
Order-5 apeirogonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Reg hyperbolic tiling stat table|Ui5_0}}
In [[geometry]], the '''order-5 apeirogonal tiling''' is a [[List of regular polytopes#Hyperbolic tilings|regular]] tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of {∞,5}.

== Symmetry==
The dual to this tiling represents the fundamental domains of [∞,5*] symmetry, [[orbifold notation]] *∞∞∞∞∞ symmetry, a pentagonal domain with five ideal vertices. 
: [[File:H2chess 25ib.png|120px]]

The ''order-5 apeirogonal tiling'' can be uniformly colored with 5 colored apeirogons around each vertex, and coxeter diagram: {{CDD|labelinfin|branch_11|iaib|nodes_11|split2-ii|node_1}}, except ultraparallel branches on the diagonals.

== Related polyhedra and tiling ==

This tiling is also topologically related as a part of sequence of regular polyhedra and tilings with four faces per vertex, starting with the [[octahedron]], with [[Schläfli symbol]] {n,5}, and [[Coxeter diagram]] {{CDD|node_1|n|node|5|node}}, with n progressing to infinity.

{{Order-5 regular tilings}}

Order-6 apeirogonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Reg hyperbolic tiling stat table|Ui6_0}}
In [[geometry]], the '''order-6 apeirogonal tiling''' is a [[List of regular polytopes#Hyperbolic tilings|regular]] tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of {∞,6}.

== Symmetry==
The dual to this tiling represents the fundamental domains of [∞,6*] symmetry, [[orbifold notation]] *∞∞∞∞∞∞ symmetry, a hexagonal domain with five ideal vertices. 
: [[File:H2chess 26ib.png|120px]]

The order-6 apeirogonal tiling can be uniformly colored with 6 colored apeirogons around each vertex, and coxeter diagram: {{CDD|labelinfin|branch_11|iaib|nodes_11|split2-ii|node_1}}, except ultraparallel branches on the diagonals.

== Related polyhedra and tiling ==

This tiling is also topologically related as a part of sequence of regular polyhedra and tilings with four faces per vertex, starting with the [[octahedron]], with [[Schläfli symbol]] {n,6}, and [[Coxeter diagram]] {{CDD|node_1|n|node|6|node}}, with ''n'' progressing to infinity.

{{Order-6 regular tilings}}

{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Reg hyperbolic tiling stat table|U66_0}}
In [[geometry]], the '''order-6 hexagonal tiling''' is a [[List_of_regular_polytopes#Hyperbolic_tilings|regular]] tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of {6,6} and is [[self-dual]].

== Symmetry ==
This tiling represents a hyperbolic [[kaleidoscope]] of 6 mirrors defining a regular hexagon fundamental domain. This symmetry by [[orbifold notation]] is called *333333 with 6 order-3 mirror intersections. In [[Coxeter notation]] can be represented as [6<sup>*</sup>,6], removing two of three mirrors (passing through the hexagon center) in the [6,6] symmetry.

The even/odd fundamental domains of this [[kaleidoscope]] can be seen in the alternating colorings of the {{CDD|node_1|split1-66|branch}} tiling:
:[[File:H2 tiling 366-2.png|240px]]

== Related polyhedra and tiling ==
This tiling is topologically related as a part of sequence of regular tilings with order-6 vertices with [[Schläfli symbol]] {n,6}, and [[Coxeter diagram]] {{CDD|node_1|n|node|6|node}}, progressing to infinity.
{{Order-6 regular tilings}}

pages.title: Order-7 heptagrammic tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Reg hyperbolic tiling stat table|U7H_2}}
In [[geometry]], the '''order-7 heptagrammic tiling''' is a tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]] by overlapping [[heptagram]]s.

==Description==
This tiling is a [[List_of_regular_polytopes#Hyperbolic_tilings|regular]] star-tiling, and has [[Schläfli symbol]] of {7/2,7}. The heptagrams forming the tiling are of type {7/2}, [[File:Obtuse heptagram.svg|40px]]. The overlapping heptagrams subdivide the hyperbolic plane into isosceles triangles, 14 of which form each heptagram.

Each point of the hyperbolic plane that does not lie on a heptagram edge belongs to the central heptagon of one heptagram, and is in one of the points of exactly one other heptagram. The [[winding number]] of each heptagram around its points is one, and the winding number around the central heptagon is two, so adding these two numbers together, each point of the plane is surrounded three times; that is, the [[Density (polytope)|density]] of the tiling is 3.

In the Euclidean plane, a heptagram of type {7/2} would have angles of 3{{pi}}/7 at its vertices, but in the hyperbolic plane heptagrams can have the sharper vertex angle 2{{pi}}/7 that is needed to make exactly seven other heptagrams meet up at the center of each heptagram of the tiling.

== Related tilings==
It has the same [[vertex arrangement]] as the regular [[order-7 triangular tiling]], {3,7}. The full set of edges coincide with the edges of a [[heptakis heptagonal tiling]].  The valance 6 vertices in this tiling are false-vertices in the [[heptagram]]mic one caused by crossed edges.
:[[File:Order-7 triangular tiling.svg|160px]][[File:Order3 heptakis heptagonal til.png|160px]]

It is related to a [[Kepler-Poinsot polyhedron]], the [[small stellated dodecahedron]], {5/2,5}, which is polyhedron and a [[Density (polytope)|density]]-3 regular star-tiling on the sphere:
:[[File:Small stellated dodecahedron tiling.png|240px]]

==References==
* [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{isbn|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations)
* {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}}

==See also==

pages.title: Order-7 square tiling
Order-7 triangular tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Reg hyperbolic tiling stat table|U73_2}} In [[geometry]], the '''order-7 triangular tiling''' is a [[regular hyperbolic tiling|regular tiling]] of the [[hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]] with a [[Schläfli symbol]] of {3,7}. [[File:H3_337_UHS_plane_at_infinity.png|thumb|The [[Order-7 tetrahedral honeycomb|{3,3,7}]] honeycomb has {3,7} vertex figures.]] == Hurwitz surfaces == {{see|Hurwitz surface}} The symmetry group of the tiling is the [[(2,3,7) triangle group]], and a fundamental domain for this action is the (2,3,7) [[Schwarz triangle]]. This is the smallest hyperbolic Schwarz triangle, and thus, by the proof of [[Hurwitz's automorphisms theorem]], the tiling is the universal tiling that covers all [[Hurwitz surface]]s (the Riemann surfaces with maximal symmetry group), giving them a triangulation whose symmetry group equals their automorphism group as Riemann surfaces. The smallest of these is the [[Klein quartic]], the most symmetric genus 3 surface, together with a tiling by 56 triangles, meeting at 24 vertices, with symmetry group the simple group of order 168, known as [[PSL(2,7)]]. The resulting surface can in turn be polyhedrally [[immersion (mathematics)|immersed]] into Euclidean 3-space, yielding the [[small cubicuboctahedron]]. The dual [[order-3 heptagonal tiling]] has the same symmetry group, and thus yields heptagonal tilings of Hurwitz surfaces. {| class=wikitable width=480 |[[File:3-7 kisrhombille.svg|240px]]
The symmetry group of the order-7 triangular tiling has fundamental domain the (2,3,7) [[Schwarz triangle]], which yields this tiling. |[[File:Small cubicuboctahedron.png|160px|240px]]
The [[small cubicuboctahedron]] is a polyhedral immersion of the [[Klein quartic]],{{Harv|Richter}} Note each face in the polyhedron consist of multiple faces in the tiling – two triangular faces constitute a square face and so forth, as per [http://homepages.wmich.edu/~drichter/images/mathieu/hypercolors.jpg this explanatory image]. which, like all [[Hurwitz surface]]s, is a quotient of this tiling. |} == Related polyhedra and tiling == It is related to two star-tilings by the same [[vertex arrangement]]: the [[order-7 heptagrammic tiling]], {7/2,7}, and [[heptagrammic-order heptagonal tiling]], {7,7/2}. This tiling is topologically related as a part of sequence of regular polyhedra with [[Schläfli symbol]] {3,p}. {{Triangular regular tiling}} From a [[Wythoff construction]] there are eight hyperbolic [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform tilings]] that can be based from the regular heptagonal tiling. Drawing the tiles colored as red on the original faces, yellow at the original vertices, and blue along the original edges, there are 8 forms. {{Heptagonal tiling table}} ==See also== {{Commonscat|Order-7 triangular tiling}} *[[Order-7 tetrahedral honeycomb]] *[[List of regular polytopes]] *[[List of uniform planar tilings]] *[[Tilings of regular polygons]] *[[Triangular tiling]] *[[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{refbegin}} * [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{isbn|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations) * {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}} * {{citation | ref = {{harvid|Richter}} | first = David A. | last = Richter | url = http://homepages.wmich.edu/~drichter/mathieu.htm | title = How to Make the Mathieu Group M24 | accessdate = 2010-04-15 }} {{refend}} == External links == *{{MathWorld | urlname= HyperbolicTiling | title = Hyperbolic tiling}} *{{MathWorld | urlname=PoincareHyperbolicDisk | title = Poincaré hyperbolic disk }} * [http://bork.hampshire.edu/~bernie/hyper/ Hyperbolic and Spherical Tiling Gallery] * [http://geometrygames.org/KaleidoTile/index.html KaleidoTile 3: Educational software to create spherical, planar and hyperbolic tilings] * [http://www.plunk.org/~hatch/HyperbolicTesselations Hyperbolic Planar Tessellations, Don Hatch] {{Tessellation}} [[Category:Hyperbolic tilings]] [[Category:Isogonal tilings]] [[Category:Isohedral tilings]] [[Category:Order-7 tilings]] [[Category:Regular tilings]] [[Category:Triangular tilings]]

Order-8 triangular tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Reg hyperbolic tiling stat table|U83_2}} In [[geometry]], the '''order-8 triangular tiling''' is a [[regular hyperbolic tiling|regular tiling]] of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It is represented by [[Schläfli symbol]] of ''{3,8}'', having eight regular [[triangle]]s around each vertex. == Uniform colorings == The half symmetry [1+,8,3] = [(4,3,3)] can be shown with alternating two colors of triangles: :[[File:H2_tiling_334-4.png|240px]] == Symmetry== [[File:Octagonal_tiling_with_444_mirror_lines.png|thumb|left|Octagonal tiling with *444 mirror lines, {{CDD|node_c1|split1-44|branch_c3-2|label4}}.]] From [(4,4,4)] symmetry, there are 15 small index subgroups (7 unique) by mirror removal and alternation operators. Mirrors can be removed if its branch orders are all even, and cuts neighboring branch orders in half. Removing two mirrors leaves a half-order gyration point where the removed mirrors met. In these images fundamental domains are alternately colored black and white, and mirrors exist on the boundaries between colors. Adding 3 bisecting mirrors across each fundamental domains creates [[832 symmetry]]. The [[subgroup index]]-8 group, [(1+,4,1+,4,1+,4)] (222222) is the [[commutator subgroup]] of [(4,4,4)]. A larger subgroup is constructed [(4,4,4*)], index 8, as (2*2222) with gyration points removed, becomes (*22222222). The symmetry can be doubled to [[842 symmetry]] by adding a bisecting mirror across the fundamental domains. The symmetry can be extended by 6, as [[832 symmetry]], by 3 bisecting mirrors per domain. {{-}} {| class=wikitable |+ Small index subgroups of [(4,4,4)] (*444) |- align=center ![[Subgroup index|Index]] !1 !colspan=3|2 !colspan=2|4 |- align=center !Diagram |[[File:444_symmetry_mirrors.png|120px]] |[[File:444_symmetry_a00.png|120px]] |[[File:444_symmetry_0a0.png|120px]] |[[File:444_symmetry_00a.png|120px]] |[[File:444_symmetry_ab0.png|120px]] |[[File:444_symmetry_xxx.png|120px]] |- align=center ![[Coxeter notation|Coxeter]] |[(4,4,4)]

{{CDD|node_c1|split1-44|branch_h0c2|label4}} = {{CDD|label4|branch_c1-2|2a2b-cross|branch_c1-2|label4}} |[(4,4,1+,4)]
{{CDD|node_c1|split1-44|branch_c3h0|label4}} = {{CDD|label4|branch_c1-3|2a2b-cross|branch_c1-3|label4}} |[(1+,4,1+,4,4)]

{{CDD|labelh|node|split1-44|branch_h0h0|label4}} = {{CDD|node_h4|split1-44|branch_h4h4|label4}} |- align=center !Orbifold |444 |colspan=3|4242 |colspan=2|222222 |- align=center !colspan=7|Radical subgroups |- align=center !Index !colspan=3|8 !colspan=3|16 |- align=center !Diagram |[[File:444 symmetry 0zz.png|120px]] |[[File:444 symmetry z0z.png|120px]] |[[File:444 symmetry zz0.png|120px]] |[[File:444 symmetry azz.png|120px]] |[[File:444 symmetry zaz.png|120px]] |[[File:444 symmetry zza.png|120px]] |- align=center !Coxeter |[(4,4*,4)] |[(4,4,4*)] |[(4*,4,4)] |[(4,4*,4)]+ |[(4,4,4*)]+ |[(4*,4,4)]+ |- align=center !Orbifold |colspan=3|*22222222 |colspan=3|22222222 |} == Related polyhedra and tilings == [[File:H3_338_UHS_plane_at_infinity.png|thumb|The [[Order-8 tetrahedral honeycomb|{3,3,8}]] honeycomb has {3,8} vertex figures.]] {{Triangular regular tiling}} From a [[Wythoff construction]] there are ten hyperbolic [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform tilings]] that can be based from the regular octagonal and order-8 triangular tilings. Drawing the tiles colored as red on the original faces, yellow at the original vertices, and blue along the original edges, there are 10 forms. {{Octagonal tiling table}} {{Order-8 regular tilings}} It can also be generated from the (4 3 3) hyperbolic tilings: {{Order 4-3-3 tiling table}} {{Order 4-4-4 tiling table}} ==See also== {{Commonscat|Order-8 triangular tiling}} *[[Order-8 tetrahedral honeycomb]] *[[Tilings of regular polygons]] *[[List of uniform planar tilings]] *[[List of regular polytopes]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{refbegin}} * [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{ISBN|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations) * {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}} {{refend}} == External links == *{{MathWorld | urlname= HyperbolicTiling | title = Hyperbolic tiling}} *{{MathWorld | urlname=PoincareHyperbolicDisk | title = Poincaré hyperbolic disk }} * [http://bork.hampshire.edu/~bernie/hyper/ Hyperbolic and Spherical Tiling Gallery] * [http://geometrygames.org/KaleidoTile/index.html KaleidoTile 3: Educational software to create spherical, planar and hyperbolic tilings] * [http://www.plunk.org/~hatch/HyperbolicTesselations Hyperbolic Planar Tessellations, Don Hatch] {{Tessellation}} [[Category:Hyperbolic tilings]] [[Category:Isogonal tilings]] [[Category:Isohedral tilings]] [[Category:Order-8 tilings]] [[Category:Regular tilings]] [[Category:Triangular tilings]]

pages.title: Rhombihexaoctagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U86_02}}
In [[geometry]], the '''rhombihexaoctagonal tiling''' is a semiregular tiling of the hyperbolic plane. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of rr{8,6}.

== Symmetry ==
The dual tiling, called a '''deltoidal hexaoctagonal tiling''' represent the fundamental domains of *4232 symmetry, a half symmetry of [[862 symmetry|[8,6], (*862)]] as [8,1<sup>+</sup>,6].
: [[File:862_symmetry_0a0.png|160px]]

== Related polyhedra and tilings ==

From a [[Wythoff construction]] there are fourteen hyperbolic [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform tilings]] that can be based from the regular order-6 octagonal tiling. 

Drawing the tiles colored as red on the original faces, yellow at the original vertices, and blue along the original edges, there are 7 forms with full [8,6] symmetry, and 7 with subsymmetry.

{{Order 8-6 tiling table}}

== See also ==
{{Commonscat|Uniform tiling 4-6-4-8}}

* [[List of uniform planar tilings]]

pages.title: Rhombipentahexagonal tiling
Rhombitetraapeirogonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|Ui4_02}} In [[geometry]], the '''rhombitetraapeirogonal tiling''' is a uniform tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of rr{∞,4}. == Constructions == There are two uniform constructions of this tiling, one from [∞,4] or (*∞42) symmetry, and secondly removing the mirror middle, [∞,1+,4], gives a rectangular fundamental domain [∞,∞,∞], (*∞222). {| class=wikitable width=360 |+ Two uniform constructions of 4.4.4.∞ |- align=center !Name |Rhombitetrahexagonal tiling | |- align=center !Image |[[File:H2 tiling 24i-5.png|180px]] |[[File:Uniform tiling i222-t0123.png|180px]] |- align=center ![[Hyperbolic symmetry|Symmetry]] |[∞,4]
([[i42 symmetry|*∞42]])
{{CDD|node_c1|infin|node_c3|4|node_c2}} |[∞,∞,∞] = [∞,1+,4]
([[i222 symmetry|*∞222]])
{{CDD|nodeab_c1-2|ia2b-cross|nodeab_c1-2}} |- align=center ![[Schläfli symbol]] |rr{∞,4} |t0,1,2,3{∞,∞,∞} |- align=center ![[Coxeter diagram]] |{{CDD|node_1|infin|node|4|node_1}} |{{CDD|nodes_11|ia2b-cross|nodes_11}} |} == Symmetry == The dual of this tiling, called a '''deltoidal tetraapeirogonal tiling''' represents the fundamental domains of (*∞222) orbifold symmetry. Its fundamental domain is a [[Lambert quadrilateral]], with 3 right angles. :[[File:H2chess 24id.png|200px]][[File:Deltoidal tetraapeirogonal tiling.png|200px]] == Related polyhedra and tiling == {{Expanded4 table}} {{Order i-4 tiling table}} ==See also== {{Commons category|Uniform tiling 4-4-4-i}} *[[Square tiling]] *[[Tilings of regular polygons]] *[[List of uniform planar tilings]] *[[List of regular polytopes]] ==References== * [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{ISBN|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations) * {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}} == External links == *{{MathWorld | urlname= HyperbolicTiling | title = Hyperbolic tiling}} *{{MathWorld | urlname=PoincareHyperbolicDisk | title = Poincaré hyperbolic disk }} * [http://bork.hampshire.edu/~bernie/hyper/ Hyperbolic and Spherical Tiling Gallery] * [http://geometrygames.org/KaleidoTile/index.html KaleidoTile 3: Educational software to create spherical, planar and hyperbolic tilings] * [http://www.plunk.org/~hatch/HyperbolicTesselations Hyperbolic Planar Tessellations, Don Hatch] {{Tessellation}} [[Category:Hyperbolic tilings]] [[Category:Isogonal tilings]] [[Category:Uniform tilings]]

pages.title: Rhombitetraheptagonal tiling
Rhombitetrahexagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U64_02}} In [[geometry]], the '''rhombitetrahexagonal tiling''' is a uniform tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of rr{6,4}. It can be seen as constructed as a [[Rectification (geometry)|rectified]] [[tetrahexagonal tiling]], r{6,4}, as well as an [[Expansion (geometry)|expanded]] [[order-4 hexagonal tiling]] or expanded [[order-6 square tiling]]. == Constructions == There are two uniform constructions of this tiling, one from [6,4] or (*642) symmetry, and secondly removing the mirror middle, [6,1+,4], gives a rectangular fundamental domain [∞,3,∞], (*3222). {| class=wikitable width=360 |+ Two uniform constructions of 4.4.4.6 |- align=center !Name |Rhombitetrahexagonal tiling | |- align=center !Image |[[File:Uniform tiling 64-t02.png|180px]] |[[File:Uniform tiling 4.4.4.6.png|180px]] |- align=center ![[Hyperbolic symmetry|Symmetry]] |[6,4]
([[642 symmetry|*642]])
{{CDD|node_c1|6|node_c3|4|node_c2}} |[6,1+,4] = [∞,3,∞]
([[3222 symmetry|*3222]])
{{CDD|node_c1|6|node_h0|4|node_c2}} = {{CDD|branch_c1|2a2b-cross|nodeab_c2}} |- align=center ![[Schläfli symbol]] |rr{6,4} |t0,1,2,3{∞,3,∞} |- align=center ![[Coxeter diagram]] |{{CDD|node_1|6|node|4|node_1}} |{{CDD|node_1|6|node_h0|4|node_1}} = {{CDD|branch_11|2a2b-cross|nodes_11}} |} There are 3 lower symmetry forms seen by including edge-colorings: {{CDD|node_1|6|node_h|4|node_h}} sees the hexagons as truncated triangles, with two color edges, with [6,4+] (4*3) symmetry. {{CDD|node_h|6|node_h|4|node_1}} sees the yellow squares as rectangles, with two color edges, with [6+,4] (6*2) symmetry. A final quarter symmetry combines these colorings, with [6+,4+] (32×) symmetry, with 2 and 3 fold gyration points and glide reflections. {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" !colspan=12|Lower symmetry constructions |- align=center valign=top |{{CDD|node_1|6|node|4|node_1}}
[[File:Rhombitetrahexagonal tiling1.png|240px]]
[6,4], (*632) |{{CDD|node_1|6|node_h|4|node_h}}
[[File:Rhombitetrahexagonal tiling2.png|240px]]
[6,4+], (4*3) |- align=center valign=top |{{CDD|node_h|6|node_h|4|node_1}}
[[File:Rhombitetrahexagonal tiling3.png|240px]]
[6+,4], (6*2) |{{CDD|2}}
[[File:Rhombitetrahexagonal tiling4.png|240px]]
[6+,4+], (32×) |} This four color tiling is related to a [[Infinite skew polyhedron#Semiregular infinite skew polyhedra|semiregular infinite skew polyhedron]] with the same vertex figure in Euclidean 3-space with a prismatic honeycomb construction of {{CDD|node_1|6|node_1|3|node_1|2|node_1}}. :[[File:Skew polyhedron 4446a.png|240px]] == Symmetry == The dual tiling, called a '''deltoidal tetrahexagonal tiling''', represents the fundamental domains of the *3222 orbifold, shown here from three different centers. Its fundamental domain is a [[Lambert quadrilateral]], with 3 right angles. This symmetry can be seen from a [[642 symmetry|[6,4], (*642)]] triangular symmetry with one mirror removed, constructed as [6,1+,4], (*3222). Removing half of the blue mirrors doubles the domain again into *3322 symmetry. :[[File:Hyperbolic domains 3222.png|160px]][[File:Deltoidal tetrahexagonal til.png|160px]][[File:H2chess 246d.png|160px]][[File:642 symmetry 0a0.png|160px]] == Related polyhedra and tiling == {{Expanded4 table}} {{Order 6-4 tiling table}} {{Order_3-2-2-2_tiling_table}} ==See also== {{Commons category|Uniform tiling 4-4-4-6}} *[[Square tiling]] *[[Tilings of regular polygons]] *[[List of uniform planar tilings]] *[[List of regular polytopes]] ==References== * [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{ISBN|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations) * {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}} == External links == *{{MathWorld | urlname= HyperbolicTiling | title = Hyperbolic tiling}} *{{MathWorld | urlname=PoincareHyperbolicDisk | title = Poincaré hyperbolic disk }} * [http://bork.hampshire.edu/~bernie/hyper/ Hyperbolic and Spherical Tiling Gallery] * [http://geometrygames.org/KaleidoTile/index.html KaleidoTile 3: Educational software to create spherical, planar and hyperbolic tilings] * [http://www.plunk.org/~hatch/HyperbolicTesselations Hyperbolic Planar Tessellations, Don Hatch] [[Category:Hyperbolic tilings]] [[Category:Isogonal tilings]] [[Category:Uniform tilings]]

pages.title: Rhombitetraoctagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U84_02}} In [[geometry]], the '''rhombitetraoctagonal tiling''' is a uniform tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of rr{8,4}. It can be seen as constructed as a [[Rectification (geometry)|rectified]] [[tetraoctagonal tiling]], r{8,4}, as well as an [[Expansion (geometry)|expanded]] [[order-4 octagonal tiling]] or expanded [[order-8 square tiling]]. == Constructions == There are two uniform constructions of this tiling, one from [8,4] or (*842) symmetry, and secondly removing the mirror middle, [8,1+,4], gives a rectangular fundamental domain [∞,4,∞], (*4222). {| class=wikitable width=360 |+ Two uniform constructions of 4.4.4.8 |- align=center !Name |Rhombitetraoctagonal tiling | |- align=center !Image |[[File:Uniform tiling 84-t02.png|180px]] |[[File:Uniform tiling 4.4.4.8.png|180px]] |- align=center ![[Hyperbolic symmetry|Symmetry]] |[8,4]
([[842 symmetry|*842]])
{{CDD|node_c1|8|node_c3|4|node_c2}} |[8,1+,4] = [∞,4,∞]
([[3222 symmetry|*4222]])
{{CDD|node_c1|8|node_h0|4|node_c2}} = {{CDD|label4|branch_c1|2a2b-cross|nodeab_c2}} |- align=center ![[Schläfli symbol]] |rr{8,4} |t0,1,2,3{∞,4,∞} |- align=center ![[Coxeter diagram]] |{{CDD|node_1|8|node|4|node_1}} |{{CDD|node_1|8|node_h0|4|node_1}} = {{CDD|label4|branch_11|2a2b-cross|nodes_11}} |} == Symmetry == A lower symmetry construction exists, with (*4222) [[orbifold notation|orbifold]] symmetry. This symmetry can be seen in the dual tiling, called a ''deltoidal tetraoctagonal tiling'', alternately colored here. Its fundamental domain is a [[Lambert quadrilateral]], with 3 right angles. {| class=wikitable width=320 |[[File:Deltoidal_tetraoctagonal_til.png|160px]] |[[File:H2chess_248d.png|160px]] |- |colspan=2|The dual tiling, called a ''deltoidal tetraoctagonal tiling'', represents the fundamental domains of the *4222 orbifold. |} With edge-colorings there is a half symmetry form (4*4) [[orbifold notation]]. The octagons can be considered as truncated squares, t{4} with two types of edges. It has [[Coxeter diagram]] {{CDD|node_h|4|node_h|8|node_1}}, [[Schläfli symbol]] s2{4,8}. The squares can be distorted into [[isosceles trapezoid]]s. In the limit, where the rectangles degenerate into edges, an [[order-8 square tiling]] results, constructed as a [[snub tetraoctagonal tiling]], {{CDD|node_h|4|node_h|8|node}}. == Related polyhedra and tiling == {{Expanded4 table}} {{Order 8-4 tiling table}} ==References== * [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{ISBN|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations) * {{Cite book|title=The Beauty of Geometry: Twelve Essays|year=1999|publisher=Dover Publications|lccn=99035678|isbn=0-486-40919-8|chapter=Chapter 10: Regular honeycombs in hyperbolic space}} ==See also== {{Commonscat|Uniform tiling 4-4-4-8}} *[[Square tiling]] *[[Tilings of regular polygons]] *[[List of uniform planar tilings]] *[[List of regular polytopes]] == External links == *{{MathWorld | urlname= HyperbolicTiling | title = Hyperbolic tiling}} *{{MathWorld | urlname=PoincareHyperbolicDisk | title = Poincaré hyperbolic disk }} * [http://bork.hampshire.edu/~bernie/hyper/ Hyperbolic and Spherical Tiling Gallery] * [http://geometrygames.org/KaleidoTile/index.html KaleidoTile 3: Educational software to create spherical, planar and hyperbolic tilings] * [http://www.plunk.org/~hatch/HyperbolicTesselations Hyperbolic Planar Tessellations, Don Hatch] {{Tessellation}} [[Category:Hyperbolic tilings]] [[Category:Isogonal tilings]] [[Category:Uniform tilings]]

pages.title: Rhombitetrapentagonal tiling
Rhombitriapeirogonal tiling
Rhombitriheptagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U73_02}}
In [[geometry]], the '''rhombitriheptagonal tiling''' is a semiregular tiling of the 
[[Hyperbolic space|hyperbolic plane]]. At each [[vertex (geometry)|vertex]] of the tiling there is one [[triangle]] and one [[heptagon]], alternating between two [[square (geometry)|square]]s. The tiling has [[Schläfli symbol]] rr{7, 3}.  It can be seen as constructed as a [[Rectification (geometry)|rectified]] [[triheptagonal tiling]], r{7,3}, as well as an [[Expansion (geometry)|expanded]] [[heptagonal tiling]] or expanded [[order-7 triangular tiling]].

== Dual tiling ==

The dual tiling is called a ''deltoidal triheptagonal tiling'', and consists of congruent [[kite (geometry)|kites]]. It is formed by overlaying an [[order-3 heptagonal tiling]] and an [[order-7 triangular tiling]].
:[[Image:Deltoidal triheptagonal til.png|250px]]

== Related polyhedra and tilings ==

From a [[Wythoff construction]] there are eight hyperbolic [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform tilings]] that can be based from the regular heptagonal tiling. 

Drawing the tiles colored as red on the original faces, yellow at the original vertices, and blue along the original edges, there are 8 forms.
{{Heptagonal tiling table}}

=== Symmetry mutations===
This tiling is topologically related as a part of sequence of [[Cantellation (geometry)|cantellated]] polyhedra with vertex figure (3.4.n.4), and continues as tilings of the [[Hyperbolic space|hyperbolic plane]]. These [[vertex-transitive]] figures have (*n32) reflectional [[Orbifold notation|symmetry]].
{{Dual expanded table}}

== See also ==
{{Commonscat|Uniform tiling 3-4-7-4}}

pages.title: Rhombitrioctagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U83_02}}
In [[geometry]], the '''rhombitrioctagonal tiling''' is a semiregular tiling of the 
[[Hyperbolic space|hyperbolic plane]]. At each [[vertex (geometry)|vertex]] of the tiling there is one [[triangle]] and one [[octagon]], alternating between two [[square (geometry)|square]]s. The tiling has [[Schläfli symbol]] rr{8,3}. It can be seen as constructed as a [[Rectification (geometry)|rectified]] [[trioctagonal tiling]], r{8,3}, as well as an [[Expansion (geometry)|expanded]] [[octagonal tiling]] or expanded [[order-8 triangular tiling]].

== Symmetry ==
This tiling has [8,3], (*832) symmetry. There is only one uniform coloring.

Similar to the Euclidean [[rhombitrihexagonal tiling]], by edge-coloring there is a half symmetry form (3*4) [[orbifold notation]]. The octagons can be considered as truncated squares, t{4} with two types of edges. It has [[Coxeter diagram]] {{CDD|node_h|3|node_h|8|node_1}}, [[Schläfli symbol]] s<sub>2</sub>{3,8}. The squares can be distorted into [[isosceles trapezoid]]s. In the limit, where the rectangles degenerate into edges, an [[order-8 triangular tiling]] results, constructed as a [[snub tritetratrigonal tiling]], {{CDD|node_h|3|node_h|8|node}}.

== Related polyhedra and tilings ==
From a [[Wythoff construction]] there are ten hyperbolic [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform tilings]] that can be based from the regular octagonal tiling.

Drawing the tiles colored as red on the original faces, yellow at the original vertices, and blue along the original edges, there are 8 forms.
{{Octagonal tiling table}}

=== Symmetry mutations===
This tiling is topologically related as a part of sequence of [[Cantellation (geometry)|cantellated]] polyhedra with vertex figure (3.4.n.4), and continues as tilings of the [[Hyperbolic space|hyperbolic plane]]. These [[vertex-transitive]] figures have (*n32) reflectional [[Orbifold notation|symmetry]].
{{Expanded table}}

== See also ==
{{Commons category|Uniform tiling 3-4-8-4}}

pages.title: Snub apeiroapeirogonal tiling
Snub heptaheptagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U77_s}}
In [[geometry]], the '''snub heptaheptagonal tiling''' is a [[Uniform tiling|uniform]] tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of sr{7,7}, constructed from two regular heptagons and three equilateral triangles around every vertex.

== Images ==
Drawn in chiral pairs, with edges missing between black triangles:
:[[File:H2 snub 277a.png|240px]][[File:H2 snub 277b.png|240px]]

== Symmetry==
A double symmetry coloring can be constructed from [7,4] symmetry with only one color heptagon.
:[[File:Uniform tiling 74-h01.png|240px]]

== Related tilings ==
{{Order_7-7_tiling_table}}
{{Order_7-4_tiling_table}}

{{Snub5 table}}

pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U66_s}}
In [[geometry]], the '''snub hexahexagonal tiling''' is a uniform tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of sr{6,6}.

== Images ==
Drawn in chiral pairs, with edges missing between black triangles:
:[[File:H2 snub 266a.png|240px]][[File:H2 snub 266b.png|240px]]

== Symmetry==
A higher symmetry coloring can be constructed from [6,4] symmetry as s{6,4}, {{CDD|node_h|6|node_h|4|node}}. In this construction there is only one color of hexagon.

pages.title: Snub hexaoctagonal tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U86_s}}
In [[geometry]], the '''snub hexaoctagonal tiling''' is a semiregular tiling of the hyperbolic plane. There are three [[triangle (geometry)|triangles]], one [[hexagon]], and one [[octagon]] on each [[vertex (geometry)|vertex]].  It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of ''sr{8,6}''.

== Images ==
Drawn in chiral pairs, with edges missing between black triangles:
:[[File:H2 snub 268a.png|240px]][[File:H2 snub 268b.png|240px]]

== Related polyhedra and tilings ==

From a [[Wythoff construction]] there are fourteen hyperbolic [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform tilings]] that can be based from the regular order-6 octagonal tiling. 

Drawing the tiles colored as red on the original faces, yellow at the original vertices, and blue along the original edges, there are 7 forms with full [8,6] symmetry, and 7 with subsymmetry.

{{Order 8-6 tiling table}}

== See also ==
* [[Tilings of regular polygons]]
* [[List of uniform planar tilings]]

==References==
* [[John Horton Conway|John H. Conway]], Heidi Burgiel, Chaim Goodman-Strass, ''The Symmetries of Things'' 2008, {{isbn|978-1-56881-220-5}} (Chapter 19, The Hyperbolic Archimedean Tessellations)

pages.title: Snub order-6 square tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U443_s}}
In [[geometry]], the '''snub tetratritetragonal tiling''' or '''snub order-6 square tiling''' is a [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform]] tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of s{(4,4,3)} or s{4,6}.

== Images ==
Drawn in chiral pairs:
:[[File:H2 snub 344a.png|160px]] [[File:H2 snub 344b.png|160px]]

==Symmetry==
The symmetry is doubled as a ''snub order-6 square tiling'', with only one color of square. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of s{4,6}.
:[[File:Uniform tiling 443-snub2.png|240px]]

== Related polyhedra and tiling ==
The vertex figure 3.3.3.4.3.4 does not uniquely generate a uniform hyperbolic tiling. Another with [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane#(3 2 2 2)|quadrilateral fundamental domain (3 2 2 2)]] and 2*32 symmetry is generated by {{CDD|branch_hh|2a2b-cross|nodes_01}}:
:[[File:Uniform tiling 4.3.4.3.3.3.png|240px]]

{{Order 4-4-3 tiling table}}

{{Order 6-4 tiling table}}

pages.title: Snub order-8 triangular tiling
pages.text:
{{Uniform hyperbolic tiles db|Uniform hyperbolic tiling stat table|U433_s}}
In [[geometry]], the '''snub tritetratrigonal tiling''' or '''snub order-8 triangular tiling''' is a [[Uniform tilings in hyperbolic plane|uniform]] tiling of the [[Hyperbolic geometry|hyperbolic plane]]. It has [[Schläfli symbol]]s of s{(3,4,3)} and s{3,8}.

== Images ==
Drawn in chiral pairs:
:[[File:H2 snub 334a.png|160px]][[File:H2 snub 334b.png|160px]]

== Symmetry==
The [[alternation (geometry)|alternated]] construction from the [[truncated order-8 triangular tiling]] has 2 colors of triangles and achiral symmetry. It has [[Schläfli symbol]] of s{3,8}.
:[[File:Uniform_tiling_433-snub1.png|240px]]
